lines.text: Every small town has its small town band with big town ideas.
Say, that guy makes Sitting Bull look like a man of action.
Look, its a brand new, gold plated, super toned, deluxe, Ted Grant saxophone. Listen to these low notes.
Sounds like he's givin' himself the bird.
That bird reminds me of Fritz Chrysler.
Me - the greatest living band leader. The man who made America jazz minded!
Oh, and Jean and I want you to know that we hope to see a great deal of *all* of you boys while you stay here.

And I wish to tell you, I-I-I don't care for Grand Opera. No. No. No. I'm too American. Too American. Jazz! Oh, I just adore jazz. I don't know. It does, inside, it kinda does something to me. Just an Indian. Just an Indian.
Hey, buddy, don't forget I got my eye on you. You and your band, to boot!
lines.character: Chief of Police George C. Tuttle

lines.text: I've gone and balled up everything, forever.
Well, I'm afraid a plain jazz band wouldn't be quite suitable on a program with real concert and operatic artists.
Oh, Mr. Grant, what a relief to find you here.

[Posing as Ted Grant]
Yes, I was - I was just going.
Boys, are we gonna hide behind a woman's skirt?
Now, in the interests of The Police Gazette, might I ask you, if your niece has ever been photographed in a bathing suit?

[singing]
I'm just a Vagabond Lover, In search of a sweetheart it seems, And I know that some day I'll discover, The girl of my Vagabond dreams...
